Award.AwardTitle: Fall Workshop of the National Society of Black Physicists: Skills and Professional Development Strategies for Minority Physicists
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Description

This award to the Associated Universities Inc/National Radio Astronomy Observatory supports the participation of 45 undergraduate and graduate students and postdocs to the Fall Workshop of the National Society of Black Physicists: Skills and Professional Development Strategies for Minority Physicists. The Workshop will be held in Batavia, Illinois on October 27-30, 2016. The Workshop is supported by the Department of Energy and it will target 300 participants and offer clinic-style and practical training sessions related to applications, interviewing, developing research statements, obtaining letters and other career related topics. A specific forum will address the needs of junior faculty at HBCUs. Because the HBCU Physics Department Chairs meeting will also be held during the Fall Workshop, there will be a unique opportunity for a chair-junior faculty conversation regarding professional development opportunities. This provides a unique opportunity for students to interact with faculty at all levels. In addition, data will be collected on how such meetings and professional membership organizations can influence broader participation and workforce capacity among under-represented minorities in STEM, especially African American physicists. This will have help with planning future workshops for broadening participation. The award is supported by four Divisions, and the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities in the Directorates for Mathematical Sciences, and the HBCU-UP program in the Directorate of Education and Human Resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Society of Black Physicists (NSBP) 2016 Fall Workshop titled “The Value of the Minority Physics Student: A Talent Source for America’s Technical Future” took place October 27-30, 2016 at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in Batavia, IL. The Workshop focused on professional development for undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows by offering oral and poster sessions, professional development workshops, breakout sessions for student/researcher interactions, mentoring opportunities and social networking activities. In addition, the Workshop offered several clinic-style sessions focusing on job application tips, interview skills, developing research statements, and obtaining letters of recommendation and other career related topics.

The 2016 Workshop also provided numerous opportunities for training and professional development. Examples of these opportunities include:

  • Graduate School Selection and Applications Workshop,
  • Negotiations and Crucial Conversations for Your Career,
  • How to Transition from Post-Doc to Professor,
  • Careers Within and Outside of Academia,
  • How to Survive the Imposter Syndrome,
  • Work Life Balance/Time Management Strategies.

More than 150 undergraduates and graduate students attended the meeting. Impact assessment indicates the meeting helped expand undergraduate and graduate student networks, and provided opportunities to explore research and internship experiences. In addition, undergraduate students attending felt the meeting helped them find professional and peer mentors, clarify future plans, and provided professional development value for the future.

The project was a collaborative effort by NSBP, Associated Universities Inc., and Fermilab, with support from the NSF.
